_prev_prog_2.PC_OtherType: Chemicals are stored in separate containment rooms that can hold spill from 330 gallon totes plus 1o%.
_prev_prog_2.MS_OtherType: Storage rooms designed with secondary containment

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
GDC EXECUTIVE SUMMARY - DRAFT

Since 1855, AFCO has been delivering chemical, process, training, equipment and distribution solutions to leaders in the food, beverage, and hospitality indus¬tries that help them operate at the best and highest levels of sanitation, productivity and profitability. AFCO is a full-service partner through¬out all areas of the client facilities and their process management. Working alongside our clients AFCO delivers expertise and hands-on support to help meet sanitation, compliance and operational needs efficiently and cost-effectively.
The 408,000 square foot GDC facility serves as a holding and distribution warehouse for factory packaged household, commercial and industrial chemicals.  Products include sanitation and maintenance products like detergents, hand care, degreasers, deodorants, lubricants and pest control solutions.  AFCO provides a full range of services connected with our products, including consultation, training, equipment designed to deliver our products, and customer site service. 

The warehouse has been constructed with 6 separate fire rated areas.  Early Suppression Fast Response (ESFR) sprinklers have been installed within 12 inches of the exterior wall on the east and west sides of the building.  In rack sprinklers have been installed in each of the four tiers of the aerosol and flammable storage racks.  The building is 100% sprinkled.  Fire protection valves are electronically supervised with a central station signaling system.  Separate storage areas have been constructed with fire rated walls, 3-hour fire rated automatically closing fire doors.  Fire department is within one mile of facility.  The warehouse has contracted security  services, access control system, cameras, fencing, intrusion detection, perimeter lighting and physical barriers.

Products are received by truck at numerous docks along the east side of the building.  Products are moved to dedicated storage areas within the warehouse based on

product type which is programmed into the computerized inventory control system.  Aerosol products are stored in the Aerosol Storage Room or cage area.  Flammable liquids are stored in either Flammable Room #1 or #2. Corrosive products are stored in the cutoff Corrosive Products storage rooms.  As needed, products are pulled and staged at docks along east side of the building for shipping to end users.  Cross docking is conducted where products are received from one carrier, staged at the loading docks and shipped out as partial loads the same day.

The peracetic acid products are received and stored in various containers, including 330-gallon totes, 55 gallon drums, and smaller (1-5 gallon) containers.  The warehouse section of the facility stores and ships these products to customers.  The GDC site does not repack peracetic acid products from larger to smaller containers.  

Based on the materials handled, and offsite consequence analysis, the GDC facility consists of two processes - peracetic acid handling is characterized as Program Level 2, while aerosol handling is characterized as Program Level 1.

AFCO implements an accidental release prevention policy for peracetic acid handling to ensure compliance with the EPA RMP regulation.  The accidental release prevention program includes:
¿	Process Safety Information, which includes:
o	SDS sheets for products containing peracetic acid, 
o	safety information for the peracetic acid products 
o	inventory which is an ongoing update of quantities products containing peracetic acid on hand; 
o	warehouse layout 
o	design codes and standards utilized in construction and project engineering,
¿	Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)/Risk Assessment, this includes a process hazard analysis for peracetic acid product storage and handling.  The PHA analyzes scenarios that represent deviations from normal operation, the causes and consequences of these deviations, the safeguards in place to prevent or mitigate releases of ha
nd the Bartow County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).

zardous materials, a qualitative assessment of the risk of these scenarios (using a risk matrix for scenario severity and likelihood) and the identification of any recommendations to prevent or mitigate risk. 
¿	Standard Operating Procedures which include  instructions on handling peracetic acid products.
¿	Training - including training for operators handling peracetic acid products, in addition to emergency response training, and OSHA-required safety training, such as hazard communications, personal protective equipment, hearing protection, etc.
¿	Incident Investigations and Procedures - which is a list of all incidents or near miss occurrences, the results of investigation into those incidents, and follow-up documentation of corrective actions. 
¿	Mechanical Integrity/Maintenance program - inspection, testing and preventive maintenance for the equipment and instrumentation utilized in peracetic acid handling.
¿	Compliance Audits - which documents the findings and corrective actions from internal and external site audits, including insurance company audits.

Five-year accident history - there have been no accidents in the previous five years that meet the RMP requirements for inclusion in the RMP submittal.

Emergency response - the GDC site maintains an up-to-date emergency action plan.  The plan details the actions plant employees would take in the event of a release of peracetic acid, incidents involving other substances, fires, and health emergencies.  The plan details the means to notify all workers of incidents and actions to be taken, such as site evacuation and headcount; and includes contact information for local emergency response organizations, including the Bartow County Fire and EMS. Evacuation plans are available and evacuation escape plan maps can be found throughout the facility.  The site maintains inventories of emergency equipment and supplies on site.  The response plan has been reviewed with the local emergency response organizations a
